body:
This should fix #1731, but it changes a couple of things in the exception handling that I'm uncertain about.

One is that it seems necessary to keep the closure alive until the coroutine (or generator) is being cleaned up since it might still need it when handling the `GeneratorExit` exception. I enabled that by disabling the `tp_clear` slot of generator closures (although that does not mean that their parent closure also stays valid), which might introduce cases of hard reference cycles between the coroutine and its closure that cannot be cleared at all.

Also, I find it difficult to figure out what CPython actually does exactly when handling exceptions inside and outside of coroutines, because the code is split across the eval loop, the frame handling, and the generator code. I tried my best to make the behaviour closer to what I think should happen, but I'm not sure I actually got there. At least, there are more test cases now than before and this change fixes them, which suggests that it is at least better in those cases. But I also had to change a test case (`generator_frame_cycle.py`) that previously did not need GC in the case of a reference cycle but now does. I actually don't know why it worked before - it should have crashed, and I added a second test case to it that shows that it at least handled the exception state incorrectly before.

I'd be happy to get a second pair of eyes on this. I think it's more correct than before in some ways, but it feels like I missed something...

commit.message:
Improve handling of exception state in coroutines to prevent swallowing exceptions of the caller.

See #1731.
Keep direct closure of generators and coroutines intact during cleanup by disabling their tp_clear() as they still need their closure for handling the final GeneratorExit call.
Add a script that concatenates the code sections in CPython's ceval.c in the execution sequence given by the byte code of a Python function.
Move exception state cleanup into generator body code to allow a distinction between normal yields and yields in except blocks. They require different handling according to what CPython does.
Reuse known thread state in more places instead of looking it up again.
List any uncollectable objects at end of test run.
Avoid "unused argument" warning of C compilers with non-CPython.

Check frame back-pointer before we clear it. CPython can simply assert the identity in genobject.c because it always owns a frame itself for the current coroutine. Since Cython does not have frames here and uses the last frame of whatever traceback it currently owns, it's not clear if we can really give any guarantees better than best-effort here.
Pass current thread state into generator body instead of requesting it twice.
Fix a CPython comparison test in CPython 3.3 which was apparently fixed only in 3.4 and later.
Terminate generator in test to avoid having its exception state hang around, which leads to exception leaks in Py3.3 for the pure Python comparison test.
Add branch hints to __Pyx_Coroutine_Close() to optimise for the normal case.
Rename test file to match existing ticket naming scheme.
Work around test failure in Py2.x.
Only reset the frame backlink of *internally* created exception tracebacks in generators/coroutines, not the ones stored away from the caller state.

title: Repair some issues with coroutine exception handling
